_**Life Is Strange: Before the Storm**_ is an
[episodic](/wiki/Episodic_video_game "Episodic video game") [graphic
adventure](/wiki/Adventure_game#Graphic_adventure "Adventure game") video game
developed by [Deck Nine](/wiki/Deck_Nine "Deck Nine") and published by [Square
Enix](/wiki/Square_Enix "Square Enix"). The three episodes were released for
[Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows"), [PlayStation
4](/wiki/PlayStation_4 "PlayStation 4"), and [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox
One") between August and December 2017. It is the second entry in the _[Life
Is Strange](/wiki/Life_Is_Strange "Life Is Strange")_ series, set as a
[prequel](/wiki/Prequel "Prequel") to the first game, focusing on sixteen-
year-old Chloe Price and her relationship with schoolmate Rachel Amber.
Gameplay concerns itself mostly with the use of [branching
dialogues](/wiki/Dialog_tree "Dialog tree").

Deck Nine started developing the game in 2016, using the
[Unity](/wiki/Unity_\(game_engine\) "Unity \(game engine\)") game engine.
Voice actors from the original game did not appear in _Before the Storm_ on
account of the [SAG-AFTRA
strike](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_video_game_voice_actor_strike "2016–17 video
game voice actor strike"), but reprised their roles in a bonus episode once
the strike was resolved. The soundtrack was created by
[Daughter](/wiki/Daughter_\(band\) "Daughter \(band\)").

##
Gameplay[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Life_Is_Strange:_Before_the_Storm&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Gameplay")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dc/Life_Is_Strange_Before_the_Storm_gameplay.png/220px-
Life_Is_Strange_Before_the_Storm_gameplay.png)](/wiki/File:Life_Is_Strange_Before_the_Storm_gameplay.png)

[](/wiki/File:Life_Is_Strange_Before_the_Storm_gameplay.png "Enlarge")

Chloe engages in a conversation with Rachel Amber (pictured)

_Life Is Strange: Before the Storm_ is a [graphic
adventure](/wiki/Adventure_game#Graphic_adventure "Adventure game") played
from a [third-person view](/wiki/Virtual_camera_system#Third-person_view
"Virtual camera system"). The player assumes control of sixteen-year-old Chloe
Price, three years prior to _[Life Is Strange](/wiki/Life_Is_Strange "Life Is
Strange")_. Unlike its predecessor, the game does not include [time
travel](/wiki/Time_travel "Time travel"). Instead, _Before the Storm_ features
the ability "Backtalk", with which the player can call upon Chloe to get out
of certain precarious situations; "Backtalk" may also make a situation worse.
A [dialogue tree](/wiki/Dialog_tree "Dialog tree") is used when a conversation
or commentary is prompted. Occasional decisions will temporarily or
permanently change outcomes. The environment can be interacted with and
altered, including marking walls with [graffiti](/wiki/Graffiti
"Graffiti").[2][3]

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Life_Is_Strange:_Before_the_Storm&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Plot")]

In her hometown of Arcadia Bay, sixteen-year-old Chloe Price sneaks into a
house concert at an old mill. Conflict arises with two men inside, whom she
evades when schoolmate Rachel Amber causes a distraction. The next day, Chloe
and Rachel reunite at Blackwell Academy and decide to ditch class, stowing
away on a cargo train and ending up at a [lookout
point](/wiki/Scenic_viewpoint "Scenic viewpoint"). They people-watch through a
viewfinder and see a man and woman kiss in the park, which upsets Rachel. They
steal wine from local campers and take a walk to a scrapyard. Chloe confronts
Rachel about her change in mood, but is refused an answer. After Rachel
leaves, Chloe discovers the wrecked car in which her father was killed. She
meets up with Rachel again, who discloses that she witnessed her father,
James, cheating on her mother through the viewfinder. Rachel destroys a family
photo in a burning trash bin, and in a fit of rage kicks it over, igniting a
[wildfire](/wiki/Wildfire "Wildfire").[4]

The next day, Chloe and Rachel are reprimanded by Principal Wells for ditching
school. Chloe hides out at the scrapyard where she finds an old truck in need
of repairing. She then receives a call from local drug dealer Frank Bowers,
who arranges a meeting to discuss settling her debt with him. Chloe agrees to
repay him by helping him steal money from her classmate Drew, who owes Frank a
large sum. However, Chloe finds out that Drew is being violently extorted by
another drug dealer, Damon Merrick, and she must decide whether to pay off the
dealer with the stolen money to protect Drew or keep it. When later a student
is unable to participate in the school's theater production of _[The
Tempest](/wiki/The_Tempest "The Tempest")_ due to road closures from the
wildfire, Chloe reluctantly takes on the role opposite Rachel. After the play,
they decide to leave Arcadia Bay with the newly repaired truck and return to
Rachel's house to pack. There, following a confrontation, James reveals that
the woman they saw him kissing was not a mistress, but in fact Rachel's
biological mother.[5]

Rachel is told that her mother, Sera, is a drug addict, and that on the day
her father kissed her, he had rejected Sera's plea to see Rachel. Chloe vows
to find Rachel's mother, against James' wishes. Chloe contacts Frank, who
agrees to meet her at the scrapyard. She repairs the truck there before Rachel
arrives. They are ambushed by Frank and Damon, who stabs Rachel after he
realises she is the district attorney's daughter. Surviving the wound, Rachel
recovers at the hospital. Chloe continues the search by investigating James'
office for clues about Sera, instead revealing that James has been in contact
with Damon; Chloe uses James' phone to convince Damon to disclose where Sera
is located, and finds out that Damon has kidnapped her for ransom. She races
to Damon to pay him off, but learns when she reaches him that James wanted him
to kill Sera. Frank appears and fights Damon, after which Sera entreats that
Chloe never tell Rachel about James' actions. Back at the hospital, Chloe is
faced with a choice: tell Rachel everything or protect her from the truth.[6]

##
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Life_Is_Strange:_Before_the_Storm&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Development")]

Publisher [Square Enix](/wiki/Square_Enix "Square Enix") chose [Deck
Nine](/wiki/Deck_Nine "Deck Nine") to develop the prequel to _Life Is Strange_
after the developer's proprietary StoryForge tools had made an impression.[7]
Development started in 2016 with the [Unity](/wiki/Unity_\(game_engine\)
"Unity \(game engine\)") game engine. Rhianna DeVries, who initially did the
game's [motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture") for Chloe
Price, voices the character, while the original voice actress [Ashly
Burch](/wiki/Ashly_Burch "Ashly Burch") serves as writing consultant.[2][8][9]
Burch did not reprise her role due to the [SAG-AFTRA
strike](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_video_game_voice_actor_strike "2016–17 video
game voice actor strike").[10] With the strike over, Burch and Hannah Telle,
who voiced Max Caulfield in _Life Is Strange_ , will return for a bonus
episode.[11] The game went under different [working
titles](/wiki/Working_title "Working title") during casting,[12] according to
Kylie Brown, who was cast as Rachel Amber (then codenamed Rebecca) in February
2017.[13] The music was written and performed by the British [indie
folk](/wiki/Indie_folk "Indie folk") band [Daughter](/wiki/Daughter_\(band\)
"Daughter \(band\)"), and released as an official soundtrack by [Glassnote
Records](/wiki/Glassnote_Records "Glassnote Records") on 1 September 2017.[14]
Instrumentation was employed to represent different sides of the lead
character: [piano](/wiki/Piano "Piano") for isolation, [electric
guitar](/wiki/Electric_guitar "Electric guitar") for rebelliousness, and
layered [vocals](/wiki/Vocals "Vocals") for friendship.[15] Daughter took the
script and concept artwork as inspiration.[16] The writers researched memoirs
and psychology to understand the grieving process of the main character.[17]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Life_Is_Strange:_Before_the_Storm&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Release")]

Prior to its official announcement, images had leaked online indicating that a
prequel to _Life Is Strange_ was in development.[18] Square Enix revealed
_Life Is Strange: Before the Storm_ on 11 June during [E3 2017](/wiki/E3_2017
"E3 2017"), stating that it would be released over three chapters starting on
31 August for [Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft
Windows"), [PlayStation 4](/wiki/PlayStation_4 "PlayStation 4") and [Xbox
One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One").[2] The Deluxe Edition includes the bonus
chapter "Farewell"—featuring Max Caulfield of the original game as a playable
character—three additional outfits, and Mixtape Mode, allowing players to
customise playlists with the game's soundtrack.[3]

Episode | Release date  
---|---  
"Episode 1: Awake"[19] | 31 August 2017  
"Episode 2: Brave New World"[20] | 19 October 2017[21]  
"Episode 3: Hell Is Empty"[20] | 20 December 2017[22]  
  
##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Life_Is_Strange:_Before_the_Storm&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Reception")]

Aggregate review scores Game | [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic")  
---|---  
_Episode 1: Awake_ | (PC) 77/100[23]  
(PS4) 78/100[24]  
(XONE) 80/100[25]  
_Episode 2: Brave New World_ | (PC) 78/100[26]  
(PS4) 79/100[27]  
(XONE) 76/100[28]  
  
Critics appraised _Episode 1: Awake_ the most on its character development of
Chloe Price and Rachel Amber.[29][30][31][32] Jeremy Peeples of [Hardcore
Gamer](/wiki/Hardcore_Gamer "Hardcore Gamer") found Chloe's behaviour
"endearing" and noted that her personality was portrayed with multiple layers.
Sam Loveridge at [GamesRadar](/wiki/GamesRadar "GamesRadar") wrote that Rachel
was the more authentic character on account of her more "grounded" dialogue.
Despite disparaging Chloe for being "her same tiresomely combative self" early
on, _[Metro](/wiki/Metro_\(British_newspaper\) "Metro \(British newspaper\)")_
saw her fleshed out by enduring the loss of her father. _[Game
Informer](/wiki/Game_Informer "Game Informer")_ 's Kimberley Wallace thought
the younger version of Chloe brought a "naivety and vulnerability" worthy of
sympathy. Conversely, the relationship between the leads was said to have
formed "at unnatural speed". Peeples and Loveridge favoured the "Backtalk"
gameplay feature, while _Metro_ and Wallace cared little for it. Otherwise
lauded were the story, graphics, voice acting, and soundtrack.[33][34][35][36]

Reviewers found _Episode 2: Brave New World_ to either be better than the
first installment or one of the series' greatest.[37][38] _Metro_ praised how
choices made a difference with a "profound effect" on character arc, while
Ozzie Mejia of [Shacknews](/wiki/Shacknews "Shacknews") relished in Chloe's
"genuine growth" contrasting her "fiery spirit". Similarly, _Game Informer_ 's
Joe Juba appreciated the continued comprehension of the character, declaring
this "its biggest strength". However, Juba's biggest complaint echoed that of
Wallace, in reference to the "forced" manner with which Chloe and Rachel are
made friends. Brett Makedonski, writing for [Destructoid](/wiki/Destructoid
"Destructoid"), thought that the character exposition was done "to great
effect". Most noted was _The Tempest_ school play sequence, which _Metro_
stated as their favorite; Mejia called "one of the funniest" in _Before the
Storm_ ; and Juba observed as the culmination of all past choices. _Metro_
criticized the script for being "uneven" and disapproved of the voice acting.
Mejia felt the ending could have been done away with, saying it was "a bit
drawn out", though he was impressed with the progression of the Backtalk
feature.[37][38][39][40]

###
Awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Life_Is_Strange:_Before_the_Storm&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Awards")]

Following E3 2017, _Life Is Strange: Before the Storm_ received one of
GamesRadar's Best of E3 awards[41] and was nominated for Hardcore Gamer's
Adventure Game award.[42] It was nominated in the Games for Impact category at
[The Game Awards 2017](/wiki/The_Game_Awards_2017 "The Game Awards 2017").[43]
At the 2017 [Golden Joystick Awards](/wiki/Golden_Joystick_Awards "Golden
Joystick Awards"), it was nominated for Best Audio.[44]
